subject: Shavian - ad lib
msgSnippet: By now I am sufficiently familiar and (shall I say) fluent with reading and writing QuikScript (Junior and Senior) to be willing to look at the Shaw alphabet
messageBody:
By now I am sufficiently familiar and (shall I say) fluent with reading and writing QuikScript (Junior and Senior) to be willing to look at the Shaw alphabet without feeling I'm going to confuse myself. After all, I am already multi-lingual and don't get confused among languages, similar and dissimilar.

When I'm switching from, say, Italian to Portuguese, I just need a few moments to get into the mental "set" needed and I can speak, converse, read and write Portuguese. When I next want to speak Italian, I just take a few moments to change my set back to Italian. Of course, since English is my daily language, I don't need to get back into an English mental set. It's there whenever I need it. I can do the Portuguese-Italian switch with other languages too: Bahasa Indonesia, Hindi, Esperanto. (Incidentally, the Shaw alphabet has been adapted for Esperanto, and is called La Sxavo Alfabeto .)

I thought of experimenting with multi-script switching. Once again, the Traditional Orthography is available on call, and I need to get "into the mode" only when I want to write and read QS. I thought that with a little mental focus I could do the same with the Shaw alphabet, and switch back and forth between the scripts, until I decide which I prefer.

I started this experiment by familiarizing myself with Shavian. I found it remarkably easy to pick up, and to read and write. After less than a week, I can switch back and forth between Shavian and QS.

I found that while QS is faster to write (almost like shorthand) because it is semi-cursive, Shavian with its print-like quality is easier to write because it doesn't seem so dependent on aligning Tall and Short letters on a common baseline and running the Deep letters through the baseline. Also QS has Shush and They are so similar in shape that they absolutely depend on the correct positioning to distinguish one from the other, with Shush being on the line and They through the line. And I find the Loll in QS clumsy as compared to the same letter in Shavian.

On the other hand, Shavian doesn't have any ambiguous letters, that depend on positioning, so that I can write Tall and Short and Deep fairly fast on blank unruled paper, and have no difficulty in reading what I have written even after a few days.

I'm still persuaded as to the economy of time and space that QS provides, specially Senior Script, and will probably revert to it as the standard note-taking script, but I have a question:

Question:
What do you think of the idea of using some Shavian characters in QS, where one finds them more aesthetic or easier to distinguish or easier to write like the Shavian version of Loll? After all, when speaking English we do take the liberty of using foreign words, italicizing them, ad lib. Some Latin contractions are so well known that we don't even recognize them as Latin, e.g., i.e. We don't even italicize these.

So it looks as if I'm inclining slightly away from the pukka standards that I set for myself when I started this journey. That said, I promised myself I would not go berserk with mixed scripts, not use them ad absurdam, but might use them as verbal/script confetti!
